column4: I'm trying to install/upgrade ubuntu on a computer that already has the previous version.  First I tried to upgrade using the Internet, which failed.  Then I tried using a new disk to upgrade from, and that didn't work.  So then I tried doing a fresh install and that didn't work.
that doesnt make sense, how did a fresh install fail?
I guess I didn't do the fresh install.  I scanned the disk and it said there were 7 errors.  I don't think there is anything wrong with the disk.  Should I just go ahead and use it?
depends on what the disk errors actually are
if you have a running system use fsck to check and try to repair the errors then apt-get upgrade to upgrade
I used synaptic to fix broken packages and I updated what it would let me.  Is that the same thing?
monky,  does my filesystem need to be mounted when I use fsck?
you can force a fsck at boot if you need to, though im not sure howto of the top of my heak
s/heak/head
I am able to boot up into ubuntu
so have you been able to upgrade with apt-get dist-upgrade?
I didn't try with apt-get, but it it failed to upgrade using the upgrade manager
did it give you an error message?
yes
what did it say?
I believe it said that I had broken packages, which is why I then tried to fix them, and failed.
go to a terminal and type sudo atp-get update
then sudo apt-get check
thanks, I will.  I'll have to go off line on this computer to update that one.
also have a look at the -f option in apto
apto?
thanks for the help.
